--- Russell Gold <russgold@...> wrote:

> On Mon, 20 Dec 2004 21:24:57 -0000, scottchamilton
> <scott@...> wrote:
> >
> >
> > I have a question, however basic, for those in the
> know. I recently
> > began working in a JAVA based environment which
> will begin to
> > utilize JUnit for testing. I will be using
> IntelliJ IDEA to write
> > my code.
> >
> > I cannot find basic instructions anywhere in
> regard to kicking off
> > JUnit and utilizing it's graphic interface to
> enter my suite
> > information and run my tests.
>
> In IDEA, just add your tests to the coonfigurations
> pulldown in the
> middle of the tool bar.
>
> >
> > The first set of tests will be to verify items on
> a web page and do
> > simple navigation.
>
> Then you will want to use HttpUnit or something
> similar in addition to JUnit

Also ...

You can also just right click a test (or package) in
the project window tree and 'run'

Or within the editor window of a TestCase, right click
and run.

The configurations dropdown will contain the last one
you have executed. You can click the dropdown and opt
to save the configuration. This behaviour changed
from earlier versions. Earlier versions used to
automatically save them. Probably and option
somewhere to turn that back on ... if u actually
wanted it. I find the new behaviour better :-)
